musicalLanguage.description: A straightforward 12-bar blues in G with a shuffle feel. This is the essential blues template that every pianist should know. Three dominant 7th chords (G7, C7, D7) and a simple melody built on the G blues scale. Master this and you can jam with anyone.
musicalLanguage.structure: Standard 12-bar blues: I(4)-IV(2)-I(2)-V-IV-I-V. This excerpt: 8 bars
keyMoments: Bar 1-4: G7 — four bars of the tonic. Settle into the shuffle groove.
Bar 5-6: C7 — the IV chord arrives. Same melodic idea, new key center.
Bar 7-8: G7 — back to the tonic, preparing for the turnaround
teachingGoals: 12-bar blues form — the most important structure in popular music
G blues scale: G Bb C Db D F G
styleTips: Shuffle feel — long-short eighth notes, like a lazy triplet
Keep the left hand steady as a metronome — it is the foundation
Right hand can be loose and bluesy — bend into the blue notes

measures.teachingNote: G7 — blues scale melody: G-Bb-B-D. The Bb sliding to B is the essential blues sound.
G7 — melody comes back down. F is the b7 of G7. Keep it simple and groovy.
G7 — climbing back up. These are all chord tones of G7 (with the blue Bb).
G7 — resting on half notes. Simplify before the chord change.
C7 — the IV chord! Same blues scale shape transposed. Eb slides to E.
C7 continues. Melody descends through the C7 chord tones.
G7 — back to the tonic. The familiar opening riff returns. Feels like home.
G7 — settling down. Half note at the end creates space for the turnaround.
